author: adik_sa_lego
title: just a response
review:
so as not to confuse the other readers. the auto service label is NOT A STICKER. it's a printed brick, which is one of the reasons why I rate this set high. the road signs are also printed.

got to buy back this set, still lovin' it after all these years.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Town (Vehicles) - Rescue Rig Review
review:
This is a great set to have and it's fun to play with as well.

Box/Instructions

The instruction has only two pages and there're no mistakes in it.

Parts

This set has 114 pieces and it was 9.25 USD when it was on sale. The price per piece ratio was 8 cents per piece which is a really good value for a set like this.

Minifigures

The minifig looks very cool as well. The driver has a blue cap, blue pants, a green vest, white arms and blue shades on his face.

The build

The build is very nice and easy and I also don't need to worry about stickers.

The completed model

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/6670-1.jpg[/img]


This set has very good design and it's a good addition to any LEGO city for sure. The doors on each side can be opened and the ceiling opens very nice and easy as well. We also get a cool looking hook which you can use to transport the cars. This vehicle may doesn't do much but it's very fun and easy to maneuver it.

Summary

All in all this set is an great set and I would HIGHLY recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de



Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1

Stopmotion 2

Stopmotion 3

Stopmotion 4

Review

author: James83
title: The King of the Tow Trucks
review:
I owned three tow trucks, the early and very basic 6656, the larger and more detailed 1572 and this beast. This one was my favourite.

 

The Vehicle

The truck echoes the style introduced by Set 6346 Shuttle Launching Crew. It is much more grown-up and American in style than the earlier tow trucks. The chassis has six chunky wheels and external fuel tanks which really look the part. The front has a low grill and headlights, above which are smaller indicator lights and two ridged grill bricks. Attached to the front is a big bull-bar. The driver's cabin is ordinary and the roof has two yellow lights and two big horns. Behind the cab are two huge exhausts which also carry hazard signs to the rear - a great touch and the wine goblet exhasuts at the top just look wonderful. The hazard signs feature two yellow lights, two great looking clear red sloped bricks as bigger hazard lights and a radio antenna. The rear section is made from sloped bricks and two excellent printed logo bricks and at the rear are hooks for a hammer and spanner. Inside there are holders for two road signs and the chunky hook made up from a hinge and a handle brick. This arrangement offers a better hook than the earlier single-piece blocks and is still sturdy enough. The hook has a good reach and the addition of a tow-attachment brick means to can finally get a secure tow around corners. Simply the best towing arrangement Lego had designed. Not only that but it looks 100% realistic and the detailing is stunning for what is still a fairly compact model.

 

The Minifigure

The driver is has blue trousers, the common 1990s green jacket and blue sunglasses and stuble head with a blue cap. He has a hammer and spanner to use as well as the signs to deploy on the road.

 

Personal Developments

None. I loved this practical and good-looking truck so much that I never broke it down and it became the tow-truck of choice. A little gem which in my opinion was never bettered. Why the designers had never concieved of its practical towing system earlier is a mystery. If you can get hold of this set it will make a great addition to any town and provides the muscle to move the biggest of vehicles.
